The facility utilizes a plant wide emergency notification system consisting of a remote wireless
activated rotating siren centered in the facility and hand-held radios to assist with employee notification
and communications during emergency situations.
The latest large-scale emergency response drill was conducted at PCC on November 1, 2017. The
drill was coordinated with Mayes County Emergency Management, Pryor Fire Department, Mayes
Emergency Services Trust Authority, Hillcrest Medical Center, Oklahoma State Department of Health,
Mayes County Department of Health, Air-Evac, Tulsa Life Flight, and the Mayes Country Sheriff. This
drill was planned over the course of many months with the purpose of exercising the emergency
preparedness and interoperability of the Pryor Chemical personnel with outside response agencies. The
emergency scenario involved a disturbed truck driver who purposefully began releasing ammonia from his
truck while on the PCC site. The drill was attended by observers with a follow-up meeting to critique the
event.

addition, PCC has recently implemented the Safety Interaction Process at the facility which creates an
interactive approach for management to be involved with associates performing in-field work processes.

3.4 Five-Year Accident History
The following is a brief summary of significant accidental chemical releases involving materials
covered under EPA’s RMP Rule during the previous five years.
3.4.1 Anhydrous Ammonia
As required by §68.42(a) in the RMP Rule, PCC has reviewed its Five-Year Accident
History for its covered processes. The regulation requires the inclusion of accidental releases from
covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known
offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental
damage.
There has been one release event at PCC over the past 5 years that could potentially meet
the criterion of significant on-site property damage. The referenced event occurred on May 14,
2020 and involved the high-pressure release of 3,400 lbs of anhydrous ammonia from failed piping
in the Ammonia Plant. The release resulted in minor on-site equipment damage. The incident
investigation showed that there were weld quality issues at the pipe fracture, and the original piping
support was inadequate. The event was reported to the NRC under Case No.1277211. There were
no on-site or off-site deaths, injuries or evacuations associated with this event.
There have been no other release events in the 5-year period that meet the reporting criteria
for on-site or off-site consequences.July 22, 2022 5
3.5 Emergency Response Programs
PCC maintains a written Emergency Action Plan, which provides the essential planning and
training for effectively protecting the workers, the public, and the environment during emergencies. The
plan contains procedures for emergency response, such as first aid and medical treatment, evacuations,
notification to local emergency response agencies and the public, and post incident measu

dent Investigation
PCC promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in a release of a regulated
substance. Additionally, incidents involving near misses are investigated. These investigations are
undertaken to identify the root cause of the incident, as well as any corrective actions needed to
prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of five years.
3.2.10 Employee Participation
PCC believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.
Employees are strongly encouraged to be knowledgeable with the facility’s RMP program and
express their views concerning accident prevention issues and recommended improvements.
Employees have access to the facility’s RMP program and information resulting from process
hazard analyses.
3.2.11 Hot Work Permits
PCC has in place a standard hot work procedure, which establishes a system to ensure
adequate controls are maintained to detect and eliminate hazardous conditions associated with fire
or “hot work”. The system dictates the coordination of hot work, pre-permit preparations, fire
watch requirements, air monitoring, personnel protection equipment, special precautions, and other
department responsibilities.July 22, 2022 4
3.2.12 Contractors
PCC hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.
Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the safety performance of the contractor is
conducted. Only contractors that meet the company’s safety expectations are hired to provide
services. Contractors are informed of all procedures for emergency response, should an accidental
release of a regulated substance occur.
3.3 Chemical Specific Release Prevention Steps
PCC has instituted several process controls to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases from the
ammonia produced and stored at the facility. Passive mitigation systems include earthen dikes, drains, and
sumps. Active mitigation systems include sprinkler systems, scrub

tup, normal operations, normal shutdown, and emergency
shutdown. Operating procedures are regularly reviewed and are readily accessible to operators
involved in the respective processes.
3.2.4 Training
PCC has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are
operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.
Refresher training is provided continuously for operator certification.
3.2.5 Mechanical Integrity
PCC carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper
operations. Process equipment examined by these checks include:
 Pressure Vessels;
 Storage tanks;
 Piping Systems;
 Relief and Vent Systems;
 Emergency Shutdown Systems;
 Key Valves;
 Controls;
 Pumps; and,
 Loading Areas.July 22, 2022 3
Maintenance is completed by qualified personnel, and any equipment deficiencies
identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.
3.2.6 Management of Change (MOC)
Written procedures are in place at PCC to manage changes in processes, equipment,
chemical storage or transfer, and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any
other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly
trained, and are an integral part of the MOC process.
3.2.7 Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established
processes are conducted as a requirement at PCC. These reviews are conducted to confirm that
construction, equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup
prior to placing equipment into operation.
3.2.8 Compliance Audits
PCC/corporate personnel conduct compliance audits on a regular basis to determine
whether the provisions of existing prevention programs are being implemented. These audits are
generally conducted every year, and resulting corrective actions completed in a safe and timely
manner.

3.2 Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
PCC maintains a number of programs to help prevent accidental releases and ensure safe operation.
Also, PCC parallels the RMP Rule by complying with Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements,
as specified by OSHA in 29 CFR 1910 119. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the
release prevention program in place at the facility.
3.2.1 Process Safety Information
PCC maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards,
operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with all processes.
3.2.2 Process Hazard Analysis
PCC conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with facility
processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these
analyses is the “HAZOP”. These analyses are conducted by a team of qualified personnel with
expertise in engineering and process operations and are validated at regular intervals. Findings
related to the process hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

3.0 Executive Summary
PCC and its management staff are committed to operating and maintaining all of its processes in a
safe and responsible manner. The facility uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs
and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of its employees and the public, as
well as protection of the environment. It is the facility’s policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent
releases of regulated substances where possible. This document provides a brief overview of the
comprehensive risk management activities that have been designed and implemented, including the
following:
 A description of the facility and use of substances exceeding threshold quantities, in a single
process, which are regulated by the EPA’s RMP Rule;
 A summary of the potential off-site consequences from possible accidental chemical releases;
 An overview of accidental release prevention programs;
 A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by the RMP Rule;
 An overview of the Emergency Response Program; and,
 An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical
releases from occurring and adversely affecting employees, the public, and the environment.
3.1 Regulated Substances
PCC manufactures nitrogenous fertilizer. The facility consists of an ammonia plant, two nitric acid
plants, two ammonium nitrate plants, a CO2 plant, and two urea plants. Anhydrous ammonia (ammonia) is
produced on site from processing natural gas. Ammonia is the only substance at the facility that is listed
on the RMP Regulated Toxic Substances and stored or maintained above threshold quantities, subjecting it
to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68. The nitric acid produced at the facility is less than 80%
